member.name: F:System.Windows.BaseCompatibilityPreferences.HandleDispatcherRequestProcessingFailureOptions.Continue
member.summary: Continue after the failure. This is the default value. It defines the behavior of the Windows Presentation Foundation dispatcher prior to the .NET Framework 4.7.1. The dispatcher may become unresponsive when this option is selected.

member.name: F:System.Windows.BaseCompatibilityPreferences.HandleDispatcherRequestProcessingFailureOptions.Reset
member.summary: Reset the dispatcher's state to try another request the next time one is needed. While this option can sometimes "repair" unresponsiveness, it cannot honor the usual timing of processing, which can be crucial. Selecting this option can lead to unexpected behavior.

member.name: F:System.Windows.BaseCompatibilityPreferences.HandleDispatcherRequestProcessingFailureOptions.Throw
member.summary: Throw an exception. This option immediately brings the problem to the application developer's attention.

member.returns: If is , this method returns if the specified can be made unmodifiable, or if it cannot be made unmodifiable. If is , this method returns if the specified is now unmodifiable, or if it cannot be made unmodifiable.
member.exception: When is , the attempt to make unmodifiable was unsuccessful; the object is now in an unknown state (it might be partially frozen).

member.summary: Ensures that the is being accessed from a valid thread. Inheritors of must call this method at the beginning of any API that reads data members that are not dependency properties.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Freezable.WritePostscript
member.summary: Raises the event for the and invokes its method. Classes that derive from should call this method at the end of any API that modifies class members that are not stored as dependency properties.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Freezable.WritePreamble
member.summary: Verifies that the is not frozen and that it is being accessed from a valid threading context. inheritors should call this method at the beginning of any API that writes to data members that are not dependency properties.
member.exception: The instance is frozen and cannot have its members written to.

member.name: T:System.Windows.Input.FocusNavigationDirection
member.summary: Specifies the direction within a user interface (UI) in which a desired focus change request is attempted. The direction is either based on tab order or by relative direction in layout.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Input.FocusNavigationDirection.Down
member.summary: Move focus to another focusable element downwards from the currently focused element.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Input.FocusNavigationDirection.First
member.summary: Move focus to the first focusable element in tab order. Not supported for .

member.name: F:System.Windows.Input.FocusNavigationDirection.Last
member.summary: Move focus to the last focusable element in tab order. Not supported for .

member.name: F:System.Windows.Input.FocusNavigationDirection.Left
member.summary: Move focus to another focusable element to the left of the currently focused element.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Input.FocusNavigationDirection.Next
member.summary: Move focus to the next focusable element in tab order. Not supported for .

member.name: F:System.Windows.Input.FocusNavigationDirection.Previous
member.summary: Move focus to the previous focusable element in tab order. Not supported for .

member.name: F:System.Windows.Input.FocusNavigationDirection.Right
member.summary: Move focus to another focusable element to the right of the currently focused element.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Input.FocusNavigationDirection.Up
member.summary: Move focus to another focusable element upwards from the currently focused element.

member.name: T:System.Windows.LocalValueEntry

member.name: M:System.Windows.LocalValueEntry.Equals(System.Object)
member.summary: Determines whether two instances are equal.
member.param: The to compare with the current .
member.returns: This implementation compares the values of the , and potentially compares the values of . The component of a is a value type, so will always be a bitwise comparison. For the component, this implementation employs a bitwise comparison if it is a value type. For locally set properties that have reference types, the behavior is deferred to that type's equality determination mechanisms, because it just uses the == operator on the two values internally. By default, this would be a reference equality of the values and thus the equality of the entire would become a reference equality.

member.name: T:System.Windows.Threading.DispatcherPriority
member.summary: Describes the priorities at which operations can be invoked by way of the .

member.name: F:System.Windows.Threading.DispatcherPriority.ApplicationIdle
member.summary: The enumeration value is 2. Operations are processed when the application is idle.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Threading.DispatcherPriority.Background
member.summary: The enumeration value is 4. Operations are processed after all other non-idle operations are completed.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Threading.DispatcherPriority.ContextIdle
member.summary: The enumeration value is 3. Operations are processed after background operations have completed.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Threading.DispatcherPriority.DataBind
member.summary: The enumeration value is 8. Operations are processed at the same priority as data binding.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Threading.DispatcherPriority.Inactive
member.summary: The enumeration value is 0. Operations are not processed.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Threading.DispatcherPriority.Input
member.summary: The enumeration value is 5. Operations are processed at the same priority as input.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Threading.DispatcherPriority.Invalid
member.summary: The enumeration value is -1. This is an invalid priority.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Threading.DispatcherPriority.Loaded
member.summary: The enumeration value is 6. Operations are processed when layout and render has finished but just before items at input priority are serviced. Specifically this is used when raising the Loaded event.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Threading.DispatcherPriority.Normal
member.summary: The enumeration value is 9. Operations are processed at normal priority. This is the typical application priority.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Threading.DispatcherPriority.Render
member.summary: The enumeration value is 7. Operations processed at the same priority as rendering.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Threading.DispatcherPriority.Send
member.summary: The enumeration value is 10. Operations are processed before other asynchronous operations. This is the highest priority.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Threading.DispatcherPriority.SystemIdle
member.summary: The enumeration value is 1. Operations are processed when the system is idle.
